journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering

title-group.article-title: Fault root cause tracing of complicated equipment based on fault graph

article-meta.aff: School of Mechanical Engineering, State Key Laboratory for Manufacturing Systems Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, China

author-notes.corresp: Hongquan Jiang, School of Mechanical Engineering, State Key Laboratory for Manufacturing Systems Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an 710049, China. Email: lincambrage@sina.com

abstract.p: Fault root causes tracing of complicated equipment in modern process industry is very important for accident and economic loss prevention. Due to the structure complexity of complicated equipment, failures happen from small parts and propagate through complex pathways often leading to serious system faults. These kind of faults caused by non-critical parts account for a large part of all the faults of complicated equipment and often cannot get enough attention in fault diagnosis. In order to trace the root causes of this kind of fault, the failure dependent relationship and fault propagation mode must be modeled accurately and effectively. Fault graph proposed by H. P. Alesso is a useful tool to represent complex structure and fault propagation pathway of complicated equipment with a special kind of fault-oriented directed graph expanded from fault tree. Fault graph takes advantage of graph rather than tree to describe complex relation between failure modes of components, and uses logic connectives to connect failure modes with logical relationship. Based on the basic concept of fault graph introduced by H. P. Alesso, this article focuses on the issues of fault graph constructing and fault graph fault root causes deducing. A fault graph constructing method was firstly discussed which uses the results of failure mode and effects analysis and the mathematical tool of polychromatic matrix and can be easily performed with the least manual work. Then the fault root causes deducing method of fault graph was investigated which focuses on fault graph reachability calculation and fault propagation pathway searching. The fault graph reachability calculation is put forward from doubletons to multiple root causes so that the reachabiltiy of any steps of fault graph pathway can be calculated. The fault propagation pathway searching method can be performed to reveal the detailed fault propagation pathway. A case study of fault graph modeling and fault root causes analysis based on fault graph of a certain type of centrifugal compressor which has complex internal structure is introduced. The case study shows that the proposed method is effective for fault root cause tracing of complicated equipment.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Complicated equipments like turbine, compressor unit, etc. play important roles in modern process industry. Accidents caused by faults of these equipments always lead to serious consequences and huge economic loss. A lot of fault diagnosis methods have been developed and used in practice. The spindle vibration analysis and condition monitoring on important status variables can detect typical faults on crucial components. But the investigation from plants shows that a lot of faults of complicated equipment are caused by failures of non-critical small part. The complicated equipments often comprise numerous parts and have very complicated internal structure, which makes the failure dependent relationship and fault propagation mode very complex. Faults happening in this complex structure are always not single and are unreasonable. The logical relation between failure dependent relationship and fault propagation mode must be modeled accurately and effectively so as to trace the root causes of faults.

Many fault diagnosis methods have been researched and developed. These methods can be classified into three categories according to Venkatasubramanian et al.1 Recent research has been made continually and fault diagnosis of nonlinear system has been investigated widely. Yin et al.2,3 focus their interest into fault detection of stochastic nonlinear systems by using gradient linearization. The main tool of their method is still observer-based residual generator and detector. In this same category, Liu et al.4 has proposed proportional and derivative sliding mode observer-based sensor fault estimation and fault-tolerant control method for Markovian jump systems. Jiang et al.5 proposed another fault-tolerant method intending to solve the near-space-vehicle attitude dynamics problem by using fuzzy models and online fault estimation. In the category of history data based fault diagnosis methods, Mustapha et al.6 developed a fault detection algorithm which can detect frequency changes in signal by combining filters bank technique and dynamic cumulative sum method. The main tool is wavelet transform and the filter bank can be hardware implemented. Zhang et al.7 used discriminant analysis to obtain statistical laws of electrical quantities’ marked changes. The discriminant analysis theory is typical in multivariate statistical analysis. The artificial intelligent technique is still been researched and used in practice. Yusof et al.8 proposed a fault detection approach integrating fuzzy logic, genetic algorithm and neural network to detect faults of process control rig.

Most of these fault diagnosis approaches can detect and give the fault type when system becomes abnormal. But for large complicated equipment, fault type is not the only information needed in maintenance. Fault root causes and the fault propagation pathway is also necessary. Fault root causes tracing is a further step after fault diagnosis which aims at finding the root causes of system fault. This is very important for fault analysis of large and complicated equipment.9 The classical fault root causes tracing methods are failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA) and fault tree analysis (FTA).10 FMEA aims at finding all possible failure modes of components and parts and the corresponding fault influence on the upper components or the system. The serious consequences of components and parts failures are predicted so that the modification of design can be made in advance to prevent the occurrence of part failures. The drawback of FMEA is that the failure mode dependent relation between different parts is not concerned when performing failure mode analysis. Sometimes failures of parts are not caused by physical and chemical reasons of themselves but caused by other parts connected to them. Failures happening in one part often propagate and make many other parts and components to work abnormally. The dependent relationship between failure modes of different parts and the failure propagation are important for fault root causes tracing, but they are not taken into account emphatically in FMEA.11 FTA is a fault root causes deducing method, which performs deductive analysis of an unwanted incident through the cascade refining analysis from top level to the bottom level based on the fault tree model. FTA is a useful fault root causes tracing method because the model of fault tree takes into account the dependent relationship of different failures and their logical relation in fault propagation. The drawback of FTA is that the fault tree model represents the failure dependent relationship in the form of tree which is not effective in describing complex dependent relation between failure modes of different parts. A large number of fault trees should be built for one large complicated equipment in practice. And another defect of FTA is that the fault propagation pathway is seldom revealed in FTA.12

Fault graph (FG) proposed by H. P. Alesso is a useful tool to represent complex structure and fault-dependent relation of complicated equipment. It is a special kind of fault-oriented directed graph expanded from fault tree. FG takes advantage of graph rather than tree to represent complex correlation between failure modes of components, and uses logic connectives to connect failure modes with logical relationship. H. P. Alesso introduced the basic concepts of FG in his contribution and made investigation about reachability calculation of single or double root nodes of FG based on adjacency matrix. The author also carried out research on the FG modeling method based on system networks which can build FG model from system P&ID diagram. The work of Alesso is fundamental. But the FG constructing method based on P&ID diagram is not suitable for complicated equipment. The reachability calculation is also limited to single or double root nodes. The root causes of faults often turn out to be the combination of multiple part failures in practice.

Based on the work of H. P. Alesso, to overcome the defects of FMEA and FTA, this article proposes a FG constructing method of complicated equipment based on FMEA, as well as the fault root causes deducing method which can find reachability set of multiple root causes and can reveal the fault propagation pathways. This research aims at proposing a useful and effective method which can describe the complex logical dependent relation between failure modes of different parts in large complicated equipment by a relatively simple model, deduce the fault root causes quickly, and reveal the complex fault propagation pathway. This is important for the maintenance work of process industry which often contains large number of complicated equipments. In the rest part of this article, a FG constructing method is firstly discussed which uses the results of FMEA and the mathematical tool of polychromatic matrix. Then the fault root causes deducing method of FG is investigated which focuses on FG reachability calculation and fault propagation pathway searching. The FG reachability calculation is put forward from singletons or doubletons root nodes to multiple root nodes so that the reachabiltiy of any combined situation can be obtained. The fault propagation pathway searching method is also investigated which reveals the detail fault propagation pathway. A case study of FG modeling and fault root causes analysis based on FG of a certain type of turbine is introduced at last. The case study shows that the proposed method is effective for FG modeling of complicated equipment with complex structure and complex failure modes dependent relationship. The fault root cause tracing method can also trace the root causes with any combination and number of nodes.

sec.title: Basic concept of FG
sec.p:
Fault graph (FG) is the natural evolutionary step over a traditional fault-tree model, which was first proposed by Alesso.13 FG is a failure-oriented directed graph with logic connectives that allows cycles. The most important feature of FG is that the model of FG represents fault-dependent relation and fault propagation pathways with a simple graph. The difference between FG and common graph is that FG contains logical and connectives which are taken from fault tree. The detailed introduction of FG has been made by Yusof et al.8 A basic FG model is illustrated in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Graphical representation of fault graph.

From the definitions of FG, it can be seen that the nodes of FG can be used to denote failure modes of components or parts. The directed arcs and their logical connections are used to represent the logical dependent relationship between the failure modes. The complex correlation between failure modes and the fault propagation process can be easily described by FG. Compared to the form of fault tree, which can only describe hierarchical dependent relationship between failure modes by tree form, FG has the advantage of representing complex correlation of failure modes of complicated equipment.

sec.title: Failure modes dependency of complicated equipment
sec.p:
Complicated equipments often comprise components which are further composed of small units and parts. In system engineering, large system can be decomposed into subsystems and the subsystems themselves can be further decomposed into sub-sub-systems. This kind of decomposition can be performed to the bottom level as needed. In the hierarchical functional structure of equipment, functions of upper-level component are determined by its sub-level components and parts. Accordingly, failures of components or parts in some level will lead to the failure of its upper level component. Other than the hierarchical failure mode dependence, failures happening in one part sometimes lead to the failure of other parts that lies in the same level or in several other levels upper or down from the functional connection between these parts. The decomposed structure of complicated equipment is like the form of tree. But the failure dependent relationship between the parts is not in the same form as the structure. It is more like network form. The mapping relation between hierarchical decomposed structure and the network form of failure dependent relationship is illustrated in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Decomposed structure and failure modes dependent relationship of complicated equipment.

In Figure 2, ellipses indicate components or parts of complicated equipment. The equipment can be decomposed from top level (the 0 level in Figure 2) to the bottom level (the n level in Figure 2). The decomposed components and parts of an equipment forms a tree form as indicated in Figure 2 by solid lines. Each component and part has one or several failure modes. Some failure modes are caused by physical or chemical reasons of their own which are called root causes and indicated by circles in Figure 2. The other failure modes are caused by failure modes of other components or parts which can be located in the under level or in the same level or even in several other levels. The failure dependent relationship is indicated by dashed lines in Figure 2. It can be seen that the failure dependent relationship has a complex structure and is like a network form. This network of failure dependent relationship as well as their logical connection is just consistent to the structure of FG. So the FG can be used to model failure dependent relationship of complicated equipment and to trace the root causes of faults based on the FG model. The only problem is building the FG model of complicated equipment accurately and effectively and not through the way of completely relying on experience. This problem can be divided into two parts. The first is obtaining the failure modes and the dependent relationship between these failure modes accurately and effectively. The second is storing the obtained failure modes and their dependent relationship and transforming into the model of FG effectively. The first problem can be solved by FMEA with some modifications and the second problem by the aid of polychromatic sets and matrix. The detailed solution of the two problems is investigated below.

sec.title: Failure modes and their dependent relation acquisition
sec.p:
Each component or part of equipment has one or several failure modes, which can be identified by FMEA. FMEA is used to identify the failure modes of parts and to analysis the causes and effects of these failure modes. The analysis results are recorded detailedly by spreadsheet as shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Spreadsheet of FMEA results and the dependent relationship between failure modes.
FMEA: failure mode and effects analysis.

Failure modes and their causes and effects of parts or components are recorded in the spreadsheet as shown in Figure 3. One part of the equipment often has one or several failure modes which are separately stored in the spreadsheet by different records. The failure mode is caused by one or several physical or chemical causes. The failure mode also affects other parts or components in the same level or in its upper level, and also those in several other levels. Each failure mode is evaluated based on its consequences and classified into a certain serious level. These records seem to be independent on the surface of the spreadsheet. But the separately stored failure modes as well as their causes and effects have dependent relationship in nature. As shown in Figure 3, failure mode FMAaa1 of part Aaa has effect to the failure mode FMAa1 of its upper level part Aa. So failure mode FMAaa1 becomes one cause of failure mode FMAa1. The dependent relationship between FMAaa1 and FMAa1 is indicated by solid arrow in Figure 3. Failure modes dependent relationship between FMAaa2 and FMAa2, FMAab1 and FMAa1, FMAa2 and FMA1, FMAa1 and FMA1 are the same as that between FMAaa1 and FMAa1. Failure mode FMAb1 of part Ab has effect to the failure mode FMAa1 of part Aa in the same level part. This failure mode dependent relationship between the parts in the same level is indicated in dashed arrow in Figure 3. Failure mode FMAab1 of part Aab has effect to the failure mode FMA1 of part A that lies in neither the same level nor the upper level of part Aab, but which lies in the top level part A that has several levels of interval from part Aab. This failure dependent relationship is indicated by dashed and dotted line. From the structure of FMEA spreadsheet shown in Figure 3, it can be seen that the failure modes of components and parts and their dependent relationship identified by FMEA are consistent with the hierarchical structure of equipment and the failure modes dependent relationship shown in Figure 2. So FMEA can be used to obtain the failure modes and their dependent relationship of parts and components of complicated equipment. In order to obtain useful information from FMEA results for building FG, the analysis of failure modes causes and effects relationship between parts should be emphasized in the FMEA procedure. As shown in Figure 3, the failure modes dependent relationship between different parts is the most useful information that must be revealed and recorded during FMEA procedure.

The results of FMEA have sufficient information for FG construction. But the transformation from records of FMEA spreadsheet to FG model for large complicated equipment is still a heavy task. To make the FG construction process based on FMEA results easier and effective, the mathematical tool of polychromatic sets and matrix can be used, as discussed below.

sec.title: Failure modes and their dependent relation representation
sec.p: Polychromatic set is a useful extension to standard set theory, which was first proposed by Professor V. V. Pavlov of Russia.14 In polychromatic sets, the constituent elements as well as its entirety can be pigmented with different colors which are used to represent different properties of the researched object and its elements. Given a polychromatic set A = (a1, … , ai, … , an), the color Fj(A) corresponding to the entirety of A is called unified color, and the color set F(A) =(F1(A), … , Fj(A), … , Fm(A)) is called unified pigmentation. Similarly, the color Fj(ai) corresponding to the element ai is named as individual color and the color set F(ai) = (F1(ai), … , Fj(ai), … , Fp(ai)) is called individual pigmentation. The unified color Fj(A) and the individual color Fj(ai) correspond to the jth property of the object and the constituent element respectively. For more detailed introduction of polychromatic set theory, please refer to Alesso et al.13

In failure mode analysis of complicated equipment, each failure mode has a unique identifier and can be assigned to a corresponding level of component or part. The failure modes can be regarded as inherent properties of the component or part. The polychromatic sets theory is suitable for describing both parts and their failure modes either in mathematical expression or in computer operation. The polychromatic set A = (a1, … , ai, … , an) can be used to denote a component A consisting of components and parts of ai(i = 1, … , n) at some certain level of decomposed structure of equipment. The individual color Fj(ai) can be adopted to represent the single failure mode Fj of component ai, while the individual pigmentation set F(ai) can be used to represent the failure modes set of ai. Accordingly, the individual failure mode of its upper level component can be represented by the unified color Fj(A), and all the failure modes can be represented with the unified pigmentation F(A).

In order to avoid losing information of the hierarchical decomposing structure of complicated equipment, the components and parts are denoted by set A(k, ik, jk − 1). In this expression, k indicates the level the part lies in, ik indicates the part identifier. The subscript k of ik indicates that part i belong to level k. jk − 1 indicates the father component of part ik which lies in the upper level k − 1. Through the set A(k, ik, jk − 1), not only each part and component, but also the connection between parts and components and the hierarchical structure of complicated equipment are represented. Based on set A(k, ik, jk − 1), the failure modes of components and parts A(k, ik, jk − 1) can be denoted by Fp(A(k, ik, jk − 1)) (where p = 1, 2, … , n). The root causes of failure mode can be denoted by fpq(A(k, ik, jk − 1)) (where p = 1, 2, … , n, q = 1, 2, … , m). The denotations of part and its failure modes and root causes can be combined into a 3-tuple set 〈A(k, ik, jk − 1), Fp(A(k, ik, jk − 1)), fpq(A(k, ik, jk − 1))〉. The decomposed structure and failure modes of components and parts of complicated equipment as shown in Figure 2 can be represented succinctly by the 3-tuple set as shown in Figure 4. The dependent relationship between failure modes are not illustrated in Figure 4 in order to make the figure more clear. Figure 4.
Hierarchical structure of complicated equipment represented by 3-tuple set.

The 3-tuple set of components and parts as well as their failure modes should be stored and manipulated conveniently in computer. This goal can be realized by means of polychromatic matrix. After representation of component and its failure modes by polychromatic sets, the hierarchical structure of complicated equipment and the dependent relationship of failure modes can be described and stored in polychromatic Boolean matrix. First of all, the correlative relationships between component (or part) and the failure modes can be achieved by the polychromatic Boolean matrix [A(k,ik,jk-1)×F(A(k,ik,jk-1))]. (1)‖cij‖A×F(a) =[A(k,ik,jk-1)×F(A(k,ik,jk-1))] = F1 … Fj … FP[c11…c1j…c1P……………cik1…cikj…cikP……………cnm1…cnmj…cnmP]A(0,0,0)…A(k,ik,jk-1)…Am,nm,nm-1)
In expression (1), cikj=1 if Fj∈F(A(k,ik,jk-1)) and cikj=0 if not.

The dependent relationship between failure modes can be interpreted and stored by the polychromatic Boolean matrix [F(A(m,nm,lm-1))×F(A(k,ik,jk-1))]. (2)‖cij‖F(a)×F(a)=[F(A(k,ik,jk-1))×F(A(k,ik,jk-1))]= F1 … Fj… FP[c11…c1j…c1P……………ci1…cij…cP……………cP1…cPj…cPP]F1…Fi…FP
In expression (2), cij=1 if Fj is dependent on Fi and cij=0 if not.

The failure modes also have logical relation when they are connected. The logical ‘OR’ and ‘AND’ relation can be represented and obtained by extraction and conjunction operations of polychromatic matrix as shown in expression (3) and (4). (3)OR:If Fj(A(k,ik,jk-1))=∨j=1PFj(A(m,nm,lm-1))=1,thenFj(A(k,ik,jk-1))=1 (4)AND:If Fj(A(k,ik,jk-1))=∧j=1PFj(A(m,nm,lm-1))=1,thenFj(A(k,ik,jk-1))=1

The failure modes dependent relationship as well as their logical relation is stored in matrix [F(a)×F(a)] as expressed in (2). The structure of the matrix is shown in Figure 5(a). This matrix is a part captured from one large [F(a)×F(a)] matrix. In [F(a)×F(a)] matrix, failure modes listed in the top row are dependent by those listed in the left column. The dots in the cells of one column mean that the corresponding failure modes in left column can cause the failure mode in the top row individually. These failure modes have logical ‘OR’ relation when they cause the failure mode in the top row, such as failure mode F01 that can be caused by F12 or F13. The failure modes appear in the cells mean that the failure modes have logical ‘AND’ relation with the failure mode in the left column. They cause the failure mode in the top row together and none of them can be dispensed, such as F03 which can be caused by (F12 AND F15) or F11 (which is still denoted by dot in the cell). Figure 5.
Failure modes dependent relationship matrix and the corresponding FGs.

By polychromatic sets and Boolean matrix, failure modes of every item of equipment and the dependent relationship between the failure modes are conveniently described and can be operated easily in computer.

sec.title: FG construction based on polychromatic matrix
sec.p:
After obtaining failure mode dependent relationship by FMEA and storing them by polychromatic matrix [F(a)×F(a)] as discussed above, FG model can be easily constructed. The main procedure of FG construction can be summarized as identifying all failure modes and their dependent relationship by FMEA, describing them in the form of polychromatic matrix [F(a)×F(a)], extracting failure modes and their logical dependent relationship from [F(a)×F(a)], and representing them in the form of FG. The last two steps can be understood from Figure 5. The failure modes were extracted from the matrix as shown in Figure 5(a) and represented in a FG by nodes as shown in Figure 5(b) and (c). Then the logical dependent relationship between failure modes was identified and represented by arrows and logical AND connectives between nodes. The key step is the extraction of logical OR and AND relationship between failure modes from the matrix. Since the representation of these two logical relationships in the matrix is different, the identification procedures are different accordingly. The mathematical description of the identification operations of logical ‘OR’ and ‘AND’ relationship can be expressed as below.
Extraction operation of failure modes with ‘OR’ relation.
(5)∀k(1≤k≤m),∀ik(1≤ik≤n(k,jk-1)),∀Fj(A(k,ik,jk-1))(1≤j≤p)Fj(A(k,ik,jk-1))=∨j=1qFj(A(m,nm,lm-1))
Conjunction operation of failure modes with ‘AND’ relation.
(6)∀k(1≤k≤m),∀ik(1≤ik≤n(k,jk-1)),∀Fj(A(k,ik,jk-1))(1≤j≤p)Fj(A(k,ik,jk-1))=∧j=1qFj(A(m,nm,lm-1))

According to the mathematical description, the logical dependent relationship between failure modes can be extracted from the matrix and represented in the FG by relatively simple algorithm described below. It is important to emphasize that the comprehensive FMEA and storing the FMEA results correctly in the [F(a)×F(a)] is the precondition to build an accurate and complete FG model.

sec.title: FG construction algorithm

list-item.p: Step 1. Search of the [F(a)×F(a)] matrix. List all the failure modes Fi, where i = 1, 2, … , P.
Step 2. Establish an empty FG model. Label the nodes set of FG as A. Make i = 1 and turn to Step 3.
Step 3. Make sure Fi has been included in set A, if not then add Fi into A and add node Fi to the FG model.
Step 4. Search all failure modes that cause Fi in [F(a)×F(a)]. Label these failure modes as Fj, where j = 1, 2, … , q.
Step 5. If q = 0, then turn to Step 8. If q ≠ 0, then make sure that Fj belongs to A. If not then add Fj into A and add Fj to the FG model.
Step 6. Check the logical relation between all the failure modes included in Fj according to (5) and (6).
Step 7. Connect failure modes that have ‘AND’ relation into ‘AND’ bars in FG with directed arrows. Then connect all these ‘AND’ bars and other failure modes to Fi with directed arrows.
Step 8. Make i = i + 1. If i > P, the procedure is ended. Else, turn to Step 3 and continue.

sec.p:
The flow chart of the above algorithm is shown in Figure 6. Figure 6.
Flow chart of fault graph construction based on [F(a) × F(a)] matrix.

Figure 5(b) and (c) shows the simple FGs constructed from the [F(a) × F(a)] matrix. The node F01 connected with F12 and F13 separately denotes that failure mode F01 could be caused by F12 or F13. The node F03 is connected with node F11 and a ‘AND’ bar which further connects to node F12 and F15. The connections of Figure 5(c) denotes that failure mode F03 could be caused by F11 or (F12 AND F15).

sec.title: Completeness problem of FG construction
sec.p:
Large complicated equipment often contains numerous components and parts. The logical dependent relationship between the failure modes of the parts is very complex. There exists no single method which can obtain complete results of failure modes dependent relationship without the aid of experiences. So there must be the completeness problem in FG construction procedure. This problem can be seen from the approach of signed digraph (SDG). Although the results of SDG are very complete compared to other similar methods, the construction of SDG still needs the aid of experiences, which reduces the completeness of SDG. Similarly, there is no one method that can get all information about the failure modes and their dependent relationship. So the completeness cannot be insured. What can be done is that the completeness level of the FG model can be enhanced as far as possible. Compared to the traditional FG construction method proposed by Alesso,15 the completeness of FG model constructed by the proposed procedure in this article has improved much more. Although the FMEA still need manual work which needs experiences, the procedure is much more regular. The key to build complete FG model is to accumulate as much as information of failure modes dependent relationship. In our research, a failure mode dependent relationship analysis program and database has been developed, as shown in Figure 7. Many analysis results of common equipments and large complicated equipments have been added in. The data will become more and more complete along with obtaining knowledge and adding in to the database when the program being used in practice. Figure 7.
Interface of failure modes and dependent relationship analysis program.

sec.title: Fault root causes deducing of FG
FG reachability calculation
sec.p: FG is a special directed graph with logical connectives. The reachability of FG can be calculated based on the reachability calculation method of directed graph. The reachability matrix R=(rij) of directed graph G is a n×n square matrix, in which node vi can be reached from node vj if rij = 1 and node vi cannot be reached from node vj if rij = 0. The reachability of directed graph G can be calculated theoretically from adjacency matrix A using the formula as shown below. (7)R=⋃p=0∞Ap
But formula (7) cannot be used in practice because the index p can not be determined. This problem can be settled by the following theorems.
Theorem 1: In a directed graph with n nodes, if there exists one path from node v to node w, there must exist at least one path from node v to node w which has no more than n − 1 steps.
Theorem 2: I∪A∪A2∪…∪As=(I∨A)s, where s≥n-1 and I is the identity matrix.
Then theorem 3 can be concluded from theorem 1, theorem 2 and formula (7).
Theorem 3: The reachability matrix R of directed graph G can be calculated by the following formula. (8)R=(I∨A)s,wheres≥n-1.

The adjacency matrix A of FG (which has been obtained in FG construction procedure discussed in the ‘FG construction’ section and been represented by the [F(a) × F(a)] matrix) is a little different from the adjacency matrix of common directed graph. The elements of adjacency matrix A of FG contain not only number 0 and 1, but also nodes identifiers of FG. The nodes identifiers in matrix A are used to represent the logical AND relation between nodes. As shown in Figure 5(c), nodes F12 and F15 have logical AND relation when they are connected to node F03. Accordingly in Figure 5(a), the corresponding element of F12 and F03 in the matrix is not number 1 but F15 which means that failure modes F03 is caused by failure modes F12 together with F15. Since the adjacency matrix of FG is not completely the same as that of common directed graph, the reachability calculation results following formula (8) is also a little different. To investigate this difference, an example of reachability calculation is illustrated below.

Figure 8(a) is a FG with seven nodes and two logical AND connectives. The adjacency matrix is illustrated in Figure 8(b). The reachability of this FG was calculated following formula (8). Since there are seven nodes in this FG, the index s took 6 in calculation. The result reachability matrix was shown in Figure 8(c). The elements in the reachability matrix indicate the reachability of all nodes from A to G. There are three types of elements in the reachability matrix. The first type of element is number including 0, 1 and 6, which mean the node on the top row can be directly reached from the corresponding node in the left column, such as A (similarly B, C and D) can be reached directly from A (B, C and D). F can be directly reached from A, B or F. The second type of element is node identifier and their product, which means the node on the top row can be reached from the corresponding node in the left column as well as the logical AND combination with the nodes represented by the elements, such as G can be reached from C AND D (indicates by the third row and the fourth row in Figure 8(c)), E can be reached from F AND G. E can also be reached from C AND D AND F. The third type of element is those numbers or node identifiers combined with plus sign, which have been proved by experiment to be the indication of logical OR relation. As shown by the second row of the reachability matrix in Figure 8(c), the element is B(15G + 15F) which means that node E can be reached from B AND (G OR F), namely (B AND G) OR (B AND F). In our experiment, the reachability matrices of a large number of FGs from simple structure to complex structure with a lot of combination of logical AND connectives have been calculated. The results indicated that the product of nodes in the matrix means the logical AND connective, and the plus of nodes or numbers means the logical OR relation between the nodes. Figure 8.
Fault graph reachability calculation.

The reachability matrix calculation procedure of FG can be concluded from the above discussion, which can be summarized as following steps.
Step 1. Calculate reachability matrix R of FG according to formula (8) based on adjacency matrix A which can be obtained from FG construction (namely [F(a) × F(a)]).
Step 2. Change those elements of numbers which are greater than zero of R into 1.
Step 3. Iterate those elements of nodes which are not root nodes in FG according to the adjacency matrix, until all elements of nodes are root nodes of FG.

After this calculation procedure, the reachabiltiy matrix R of FG can be obtained. The element rij of R have four types which are:
Number 0, means that there is no reachable path of the corresponding nodes.
Number 1, means that the node on the top row can be reached from the node in the left column.
Node identifiers and their product, means that the node on the top row can be reached by AND combination of the node in the left column and the elements.
Node identifiers and their plus, means that the node on the top row can be reached by OR combination of the node in the left column and the elements separated at plus sign.

In the example FG as shown in Figure 8(a), the reachability matrix can be calculated following the above procedure and the result reachable sets of each node are A{A}, B{B}, C{C}, D{D}, E{AG, BG, BF, CDF, E, FG}, F{A, B, F}, G{B, CD, G}, where product of nodes indicates the logical AND relation, and the commas in the braces indicate logical OR relation.

sec.title: Fault propagation pathway searching of FG
sec.p: Reachability calculation of FG is mostly used to obtain the reachability between nodes through which the root causes nodes of failure node can be identified directly. But the pathway of fault propagation cannot be obtained through reachability calculation. The operator in plant need not only know the root causes but also needs to know the complete process of fault propagation so as to find out the damage made by each failure node in the propagation pathway. Therefore, the propagation pathway of FG should be obtained after reachability calculation.

FG is a kind of directed graph representing failure modes interrelation and fault propagation process. FG can describe complex logical relation between components failures and the fault propagation by elements of directed graph. The fault root causes can be traced through fault propagation pathways searching and deducing in FG.

The algorithm described by the above steps can be illustrated by the flowchart as shown in Figure 9 which is more intuitive. Figure 9.
Fault graph root causes searching algorithm.

sec.title: FG construction and fault root causes analysis of a centrifugal compressor
sec.p:
In order to verify the validity of the proposed method as discussed in this article, a case study of FG construction and fault root causes tracing of a centrifugal compressor used in a coal chemical industry plant was investigated. The centrifugal compressor is the most important equipment of the compressor unit which is the essential key infrastructure of coal chemical industry. The centrifugal compressor usually comprises rotor assembly and stator assembly. The two assemblies further comprise numerous components and parts. The main decomposed structure of centrifugal compressor is shown in Figure 10. Figure 10.
Decomposed structure of centrifugal compressor.

The common fault and failure modes of the components were analyzed by FMEA and are listed in Table 1. In Table 1, faults and failure modes of each component and part of the centrifugal compressor as shown in Figure 10 were analyzed and listed. Faults and failure modes are listed and labeled by their IDs. The IDs comprise the serial number of the component in the decomposed hierarchical structure by subscripts and the serial number of each failure modes of this component by superscripts. The ID of the top level (which means the centrifugal compressor itself) begins from 45 but not 1. This is because this analysis is taken from a large system which also contains several other equipments. The relevant common root causes of the compressor were listed at the end of the table and labeled simply from F2 to F36 with the irrelevant root causes taken off. Table 1.
Common failure modes of components of centrifugal compressor.
ID Component Faults and failure modes ID Component Failure mode
F451 Centrifugal compressor Insufficient displacement F631 Shaft end sealing Poor sealing of shaft end seal
F452
excess temperature of import air F641 Interstage sealing Poor sealing of interstage sealing
F453
Inlet pressure low F651 Balance disc sealing Poor sealing of balance disc sealing
F454
surge F671 Fins Fins dropt
F455
Import less air F681 Surge valve Surge valve does not work
F456
Small molecular weight of import air F682 Surge valve damage
F457
Low density of import air F683 Surge valve controller failure
F458

F459
outlet pressure less than the pipe pressure F711 Radical bearing Excess temperature
F471 Rotor vibrate excessively F712

F472

F473 Close to critical speed F715

F474

oil supply hole jammed
F475

F476

F477

F478
The original mass unbalanced F7110

F479
Rotor components loosed F721 Thrust bearing Small hole diameter of inlet oil throttle
F4710
Too big displacement of spindle F722 Oil inlet hole jammed
F4711
Rotor corrosion F723
Bearing bush friction
F481 Air filter Low supply of air F724
Small clearance of bearing bush
F482
Entrance mesh jammed F725

F483
Inspiratory resistance increasing F726

F484
Too long straws F761 Transmission gear Bad gear meshing
F485
Too small pipe diameter F831 Lubrication system excess temperature of inlet oil
F491 Diffuser Diffuser scaling F832 Lubricating oil pressure lower
F521 Seal components Poor sealing F833 Lubricating oil temperature lower
F522 Seal components corrosion F834 Lubricating oil leakage
F523 Bad corrosion resistance F2 Common root causes Structure design is not reasonable
F541 Pipes Too large exhausting pipe resistance F3 Poor manufacturing process
F542 Interstage cooler Pipe network system pressure out F4 Improper installation
F551 Bad cooling effect F5 Interference shortage
F552 Equalizer Cooling area reducing F6 Poor quality of material
F553 Cooling pipe scaling F7 hard particles in inlet air
F554 Cooler leaking F8 Solid impurities deposition
F561 Equalizer blocked F9 Poor quality of lubricating oil
F591 Spindle Spindle bending F10 Speed over critical speed
F592 Bearing Too big axial thrust F11 Excess temperature of cooling water
F601 Insufficient oil supply F12 Circulation water is too small
F602 Blade Oil whip F13 Excess hardness of circulating water
F603 Poor lubrication effect F14 Air with oil
F604 Oil film is not stable F31 Poor corrosion resistance of blade
F605 Low import oil into bearing F32 Poor corrosion resistance of rotor
F611 Blade scaling F33 Air contains corrosive medium
F612 Coupling Blade breakage F34 Containing SO2
F613 Blade corrosion F35 Poor anticorrosion measures
F621 Poor coupling effect F36 Containing CO2

The dependent relationship between failure modes listed in Table 1 is represented and stored by polychromatic matrix [F(a)×F(a)]. Part of the matrix is illustrated in Figure 11 because the whole matrix is too large to display. Figure 11.
Failure modes dependent relationship matrix of compressor.

Based on the matrix, the logical dependent relationship between failure modes were extracted and the FG model was constructed according to the algorithm described in the section ‘FG construction based on polychromatic matrix’. The FG model of the compressor constructed at last is shown in Figure 12. Figure 12.
FG of centrifugal compressor.

Root causes of centrifugal compressor failures can be deduced based on this FG. The root causes deducing method and algorithm has been discussed in the ‘Fault root causes deducing of FG’ section. In practice, F451 was found to be a frequently occurring failure mode, as indicated in Figure 12 by extra bold circle and filled in gray. The root causes of failure mode F451 has been deduced using the proposed algorithm. The set of root causes of F451 has been obtained by FG reachability calculation. The result is {F457, F482 (F484 AND F485), (F701 AND F542), F11, F12, F13, F14, F671, F8, F554 [(F36, F34) AND F35 AND F523]}. These root nodes are indicated by bold circles filled in gray in Figure 12. The fault propagation pathways through the root causes to F451 have been searched by the algorithm proposed in the section ‘Fault propagation pathway searching of FG’, which are {((F701 AND F542) → F541→F451), (F457→F451), (F482→F481→F453→F451), ((F484 AND F485) → F483→F481→F453→F451), (F13 → F553 → F551 → F552 → F451), (F14 → F553 → F551 → F452 → F451), (F671→F552→F551→F452→F451), (F11→F551→F452→F451), (F12→F551→F452→F451), (((F34 → F33) AND F35 AND F523) →F522→F631→F521→F451), (((F36 → F33) AND F35 AND F523) → F522→F631→F521→F451), (((F34 → F33) AND F35 AND F523) → F522→F641→F521→F451), (((F36 → F33) AND F35 AND F523) → F522→F641→F521→F451), (((F34 → F33) AND F35 AND F523) →F522→F651→F521→F451), (((F36 → F33) AND F35 AND F523) → F522→F651→F521→F451), (F8→F611→F458→F451), (F8→F491→F458→F451), (F554→F611→F458→F451), (F554→F491→F458→F451). The fault propagation pathways are emphasized in Figure 12 by bold arrows and bold circles from root causes to fault F451. All these pathways can be the possible fault propagation pathway when failure F451 occurs. But in practice only one or several pathways will be the true fault propagation pathway in one occurrence of F451. So the pathways have been sorted by the probability of fault propagating through the faults of the pathway. The pathways of ((F701 AND F542) → F541→F451) and (((F34 → F33) AND F35 AND F523) → F522→F631→F521→F451) turn to be the most possible fault propagation pathways. In the follow up investigation performed by our project team, (((F34 → F33) AND F35 AND F523) → F522→F631→F521→F451) has been found ultimately to be the pathway of compressor unit breakdown accidents for twice time.

sec.title: Comparison analysis and future work
sec.p: In all the fault analysis methods that use graph models, SDG is researched and used most widely. There are similarities as well as differences between SDG and FG. They both take advantage of directed graph in which complex relation can be represented by simple nodes and their connections. The nodes of SDG are usually used to represent state variables which have different status. The arcs connecting nodes are used to describe positive and negative influence between state variables. Therefore, SDG is more suitable for describing the abnormal status influence between different devices and equipments. It is used widely in process systems to trace the abnormal status transferring paths. The nodes of FG are different from SDG. They are used to represent failure modes. Therefore, they have no different status and cannot be used to describe state of variables. In other words, nodes of FG are static while nodes of SDG are dynamic. They are used to represent different objects. The connections between nodes of FG are also different from that of SDG. In FG, logical connectives are used to represent logical dependent relationship between failures modes. From the differences between SDG and FG, it can be seen that FG is more suitable for fault root causes analysis of single equipment, while SDG is more capable of fault diagnosis of a system which comprises of different equipments. For the systems containing several different large complicated equipment, the most effective way is to integrate these two models. SDG models are used to describe status influences between different equipments and identify the root equipment which causes system abnormal state. FG models are used to perform fault root causes analysis of the root abnormal equipment and find the root causes. In this integrated approach, advantages of SDG and FG are combined. The fault analysis can be performed from system level to bottom parts level. This is very useful for the systems of process industry. Some initial research has been done and an application investigation is ongoing which will be discussed when the result becomes desirable.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article has proposed a fault root causes tracing method for complicated equipment of modern process industry. The FG model proposed by H. P. Alesso was used to be the tool to trace the root causes. This article focuses on the issues of FG constructing and FG fault root causes deducing. The FG constructing method was firstly discussed which uses the results of FMEA and the mathematical tool of polychromatic matrix. Then the fault root causes deducing method of FG was investigated which focuses on FG reachability calculation and fault propagation pathway searching. The FG reachability calculation is put forward from doubletons15 to multiple nodes combination so that the reachabiltiy of any steps of FG pathway can be calculated. The fault propagation pathway searching method can be performed to reveal the detailed fault propagation pathway. A case study of FG modeling and fault root causes deducing based on the proposed method of a certain type of centrifugal compressor is introduced. The case study shows that the proposed method is effective for fault root cause tracing of complicated equipment. Compared to other equipment fault diagnosis methods which can only achieve good effect in small and simple devices, the proposed approach can obtain the complex failure modes dependent relationship and can be used to perform fault analysis for large complex system. Also, compared to the approach of FTA, the complex failure modes dependent relationship can be represented in simple FG model. The complex multiple root causes combination can also be easily deduced and the fault propagation pathways can be revealed and shown to maintenance personnel. These features are important for enhancing the effectiveness of fault analysis of large complex systems such as the process industry systems.

sec.p: This work was supported by the National High Technology Research and Development Program (Project 2007AA04Z432) and the National Nature Science Foundation of China (Project 61104025).

ack.p: We gratefully acknowledge the valuable cooperation of Wei-he Coal Chemical Group in accomplishing the research project.
